headline: Schapiro Letter to House Committees
summary: SEC Chairwoman Mary Schapiro responded to House committee questions about the Becker/Madoff probe.

headline: Methodology of Top 50 List
summary: The Next Big Thing 2011 rankings included a ranking of equity raised, executives' success, growth in value, and the track record of success for the board members.

headline: Senators 2, Devils 1
summary: Erik Condra scored his second goal of the game with 2:17 to play and the Ottawa Senators stunned the red-hot New Jersey Devils on Tuesday night.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: CD Yields Are Flat
summary: Yields on certificates of deposit were unchanged in the latest week.

headline: Islanders 4, Maple Leafs 3
summary: Blake Comeau's tip-in with 57.3 seconds left in overtime led the New York Islanders to a victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs on Tuesday night.

headline: China Adviser Urges Yuan Reform
summary: A member of the Chinese central bank's monetary advisory committee said China should aim for full yuan convertibility over the next 10 years, saying such a move is important for a "rising power" like China.

headline: New Zealand Cuts Interest Rates
summary: New Zealand's central bank cut interest rates to offset the impact from the earthquake that devastated the nation's second largest city of Christchurch last month.

headline: PETA Changes Its Stripes
summary: Animal rights activists have new tactics in their war against fur on the ruways, writes the Journal's Elizabeth Holmes. Still, fur was on display this season.

headline: Hoods are High Style
summary: Hoods made a strong showing on the runways during the marathon of fashion weeks, from New York to Paris.

headline: Man Charged With Smuggling Operation
summary: U.S. prosecutors charged a Pakistani man with running a smuggling operation that shipped materials and equipment to the agencies operating Pakistan's nuclear program.

headline: Red Storm Survives a Blunder-Filled Battle
summary: St. John's staggered past Rutgers, 65-63, to advance to the quarterfinal round  of the Big East Tournament in a game marred by two late officiating errors.

headline: Libyan Central-Bank Governor Is Replaced
summary: Libya's central bank governor Farhat Bengdara said Wednesday he had been temporarily replaced by the country's finance minister and had his right to sign agreements withdrawn.

headline: Long Arm of Law Reaches Out to Woo Muslims
summary: An Obama administration strategy for cultivating young Muslims is taking heat from both the left and the right, amid increasing concerns about homegrown Islamic terrorism.

headline: New Minister's Priority: China
summary: Managing relations with China will be one of the top priorities for Japan's new Foreign Minister Takeaki Matsumoto, as a couple of months of relative calm between the two countries seems to be coming to an end.

headline: U.S. to Issue Some Drilling Permits
summary: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar said the permits would be coming as he faced more questions from U.S. lawmakers about pending applications to drill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: NPR's Damning Admission
summary: JOHN FUND ON THE TRAIL  The latest scandal to tarnish NPR's image.

headline: FAA to Further Limit Eclipse Jet's Altitude
summary: Federal regulators will restrict operation of Eclipse Aerospace's jets to a maximum altitude of 30,000 feet in response to persistent engine problems on the light, twin-engine planes.

headline: Bill Offers Waiver Rights in Health Overhaul
summary: A senior house Republican introduced a bill that would allow consumers to apply for waivers to key health-law requirements, including the mandate to carry health insurance or pay a fee.

headline: Homicides Decline 22%
summary: Homicides in New York City have plummeted 22% this year compared with the same period in 2010.

headline: Massachusetts Hedge Fund Faces State Insider Case
summary: Massachusetts's securities regulator moved to shut down a small Cambridge hedge fund Wednesday after charging it and its manager with using an expert consultant to obtain inside information on two pharmaceutical companies.

headline: UAE Citizens Petition Rulers
summary: More than 100 citizens of the United Arab Emirates have submitted a petition to their rulers demanding an elected parliament with legislative powers, the first sign of a political response in the country to the political changes sweeping across the Middle East.

headline: AIG Moves to Protect $65 Billion in Tax-Loss Benefits
summary: American International Group is taking steps to protect nearly $65 billion in tax benefits, as the bailed-out insurer prepares to exit majority government ownership over the next two years.

headline: Storms Slam Southeast
summary: Tornadoes and floodwaters rumbled across Louisiana Wednesday, a suitable end to the region's Mardi Gras celebrations. Alabama, Mississippi and Tennessee were also hit.

headline: Moelis Brings On Saggese as Senior Adviser
summary: Nick Saggese, a former partner at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, has joined investment bank Moelis & Co. as a senior adviser, said people familiar with the matter.

headline: Early Win for GOP on Net-Neutrality
summary: House Republicans took the first step toward blocking the Federal Communications Commission's effort to assert authority over Internet lines.

headline: Concern Over Delay in Aid for Jobless
summary: The Obama administration has delayed for several months the launch of a $1 billion effort to help unemployed homeowners avoid foreclosure, sparking fears the program is running out of time to help many borrowers.

headline: Failed Spending Votes May Pave Way for Deal, Says Lew
summary: A top White House official said the failure of competing spending-cut bills in the Senate could clear the way for a compromise on government funding before a potential government shutdown next week.

headline: Canadian Banks Unite Against TMX-LSE Tie-Up
summary: Pressure to block TMX Group's proposed merger with London Stock Exchange Group is mounting as some of Canada's biggest financial institutions prepare to mount a campaign to oppose the deal.

headline: Tognum Bid Looks Underpowered
summary: Rolls-Royce and Daimler's joint bid for Tognum, a leading player in the booming market for longer-cycle industrial engines, looks like an opening shot.

headline: San Miguel Builds Up War Chest
summary: San Miguel is building a multibillion-dollar war chest in preparation for what the Philippines conglomerate fears will be a rapid end to a two-year-long boom in some of Asia's emerging markets.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In today's photos, surfers compete in Australia, police arrest a Tibetan exile protesting in India, young men paint themselves in oil and ash in Mexico and more.

headline: Clean-Energy Firms to List in Hong Kong
summary: As China encourages investment in wind, solar and nuclear power, two more clean-energy operators in the country are planning to raise a total of roughly $1.1 billion through initial public offerings in Hong Kong.

headline: European Shares Slip
summary: European stocks ended a bumpy session in the red Wednesday, led lower by oil majors and bank issues, amid continuing concern over the unrest in North Africa and the Middle East and as sovereign-debt fears resurfaced.

headline: Ford Looks to Southeast Asia for Growth
summary: Ford will expand the range of vehicles it sells in Southeast Asia as part of a wider effort to boost its market share in the region.

headline: H&R Block Posts Loss, Cites Slow Start to Tax Season
summary: H&R Block swung to a fiscal third-quarter loss, as the nation's biggest tax preparer said an "industrywide slow start to tax season" hurt revenue.

headline: Next Big Thing - Top Venture-Funded Companies
summary: Start-ups with potential for technological breakthroughs in health care, mobile communications and business software topped The Wall Street Journal's second annual Next Big Thing list.

headline: Repeal of Ethanol Tax Credit Sought
summary: A pair of U.S. senators introduced a bill to repeal a controversial tax credit given to companies that blend ethanol into gasoline.

headline: The Fighting in Ras Lanouf
summary: As forces loyal to Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi seized the central square of the city of Zawiya and Libyan officials tried to block international pressure on the government, rebels and government forces continued to fight in Ras Lanouf.

headline: Sarah Burton Ups the Drama for Alexander McQueen
summary: Designer Sarah Burton has stepped into the spotlight with her fall/winter 2011 collection for Alexander McQueen. With theatrical looks fit for Marie Antoinette, Ms. Burton delivered "her first tour de force," says.

headline: Europe's Economic Divide Widens
summary: Europe's economic divide showed signs of widening further, as German industry powered the region's largest economy toward strong growth, while Portugal struggled to sell €1 billion ($1.39 billion) in government bonds and Greek unemployment jumped.

headline: Crude Markets Diverge
summary: Rising violence in Libya and a surprise jump in U.S. oil stockpiles sent U.S. and European crude futures in different directions.

headline: Lloyds Retail, Insurance Chiefs to Leave
summary: Lloyds Banking Group said its insurance and retail heads will leave the group, as new Chief Executive Antonio Horta-Osorio put his stamp on the bank's direction.

headline: Methodology of Top 50 List
summary: The Wall Street Journal's ranking of the 50 top venture-backed companies was calculated based on how each company scored in four largely financial components and one qualitative one.

headline: Palin's Unpresidential Calendar
summary: It looks like Ms. Palin's calendar won't include the first Republican presidential debate.

headline: NPR Executive Quits After Video Comments
summary: An NPR executive who was caught on video making disparaging remarks about the Republican Party and the Tea Party movement to two men posing as members of an Islamic civic group resigned Tuesday night.

headline: NPR Executive Cedes New Role at Aspen Institute
summary: Former NPR executive Ron Schiller ceded his new role at the Aspen Institute after a video scandal forced him to resign with immediate effect from NPR this week.

headline: Libya Worries Boost Treasurys
summary: Treasurys rallied as signs of escalating clashes in Libya spurred demand for safe assets, with investors including foreign central banks bidding up a sale of $21 billion of 10-year notes.

headline: Gold Futures Trim Gains
summary: Gold futures pared their safe-haven gains as investors worried about the possibility of tighter monetary policy in the U.S.

headline: Thailand Raises Key Rate
summary: The Bank of Thailand raised its benchmark interest rate for a third straight time and signaled it will continue raising rates as it battles to curb rising inflationary pressures.

headline: Prudential Reaps Rewards of Plan B
summary: Prudential PLC shareholders can feel vindicated. Shares in the U.K. insurer are up 33% since investors forced CEO Tidjane Thiam to abandon a $35 billion takeover bid for AIA.

headline: Walgreen to Sell Unit for $525 Million
summary: Walgreen agreed to sell its pharmacy benefit management unit to Catalyst Health Solutions for $525 million.

headline: EADS Swings to Profit
summary: European Aeronautic Defence swung to a fourth-quarter net profit due to increased aircraft deliveries, cost savings and improved performance in non-Airbus divisions. EADS expects core profit to remain stable in 2011.

headline: European Shares Decline
summary: European stocks ended a bumpy session in the red, led lower by oil majors and bank issues, amid continuing concern over the unrest in North Africa and the Middle East, and as sovereign debt fears resurfaced.

headline: Morgan Stanley Plans Layoffs
summary: Morgan Stanley will lay off 200 to 300 trainees and lower-producing financial advisers in its brokerage joint venture, likely bringing the Smith Barney unit's work force to about 17,800 advisers.

headline: Morgan Stanley Tells Brokers to Text Away
summary: Morgan Stanley, despite concerns over regulatory compliance issues, is allowing brokers with firm-managed BlackBerrys to use them for texting.

headline: Lagardère Projects Profit Growth
summary: French media group Lagardère said it expects profits to bounce back in 2011, a year in which it aims to refocus its main media assets.

headline: Icahn Disputes Blockbuster Bondholder
summary: Investor Carl Icahn said that a disgruntled bondholder's request to block him from making a competing bid to acquire Blockbuster "lacks logic," although he stopped short of saying he would make a bid for the company.

headline: Daimler, Rolls-Royce Launch Bid
summary: Power systems provider Rolls-Royce Group and car maker Daimler offered €3.2 billion to buy German diesel-engine maker Tognum in a deal that would create a leading player in the industrial engines market.

headline: Gold Prices Pinch Jewelry Retailers
summary: Gold's record-breaking rally is weighing on jewelry retailers, as the ever-increasing cost of the popular yellow metal dims the enthusiasm of shoppers.

headline: Kores, Daewoo International Drop Bid for Whitehaven Coal
summary: Korea Resources, or Kores, and Daewoo International said their consortium has dropped its bid for Australia's Whitehaven Coal.

headline: Christian-Muslim Clashes in Egypt
summary: At least 13 people were killed and about 140 wounded in clashes that broke out when a Muslim mob attacked thousands of Christians protesting against the burning of a Cairo church.

headline: Extract Wants Chinese Uranium Bid Extended
summary: Extract Resources said it wants a Chinese state-owned company that made a takeover offer for its largest shareholder, which holds a key uranium project in Africa, to extend the offer to its own shareholders.

headline: Australia, U.A.E. to Begin Uranium Talks
summary: Australia will begin talks with the United Arab Emirates to sell the Middle East's second-largest Arab economy uranium for a planned US$20 billion nuclear power project in the sheikdom of Abu Dhabi.

headline: Libya Turns Oil Rally From Nuisance To Threat For World Economy
summary: The loss of Libya's supplies has transformed the oil rally, previously seen as a mild obstacle, into a potent threat to the global economy.

headline: Japan Machinery Orders Rise Sharply
summary: Japanese core machinery orders rose a stronger-than-expected 4.2% in January from the previous month, as orders from manufacturers were robust on the back of fast-rising overseas demand.

headline: Medtronic Resolves FDA Issues
summary: Medtronic resolved issues at two manufacturing facilities cited in FDA warning letters.

headline: Kenny to Lead Ireland in 'Darkest Hour'
summary: Enda Kenny was voted in by parliament as Ireland's new prime minister, and faces a torrid task as he leads his debt-stricken country during what he described as its "darkest hour."

headline: Micromax Cuts IPO Size
summary: Indian mobile handset maker Micromax Informatics has cut the size of its initial public offering by about 30%, reflecting the turbulent Indian stock markets this year.

headline: U.S. Vows to Resolve Trade Issues With Colombia, Panama This Year
summary: U.S. Trade Representative Ron Kirk told senators Wednesday that the Obama administration is committed to resolving the remaining issues with the Colombia and Panama trade agreements this year.

headline: Asian Shares Rise, Oil Price Slips
summary: Asian stocks mostly advanced as crude-oil prices continued to pause, while shares in Tokyo sloughed off the earthquake off Japan's northern coast and cheered upbeat machinery-orders data.

headline: China's Low-Rent Push Could Squeeze Developers
summary: If you build it, profits will come. That's been the axiom for China's private-sector property developers, and Beijing's new housing push might seem bullish for them. But it isn't.

headline: Japanese Bonds Fall Ahead Of 5-Year Tender
summary: Yields on medium- and long-term Japanese government bonds edged higher in response to a weak showing by U.S. Treasurys on Tuesday, and investors are expected to remain cautious even after an auction of five-year debt on Thursday.

headline: Asian Growth Boosts Prudential
summary: Prudential PLC's net profit more than doubled in 2010, helped by strong sales in Asia, allowing the company to distribute a bigger-than-expected dividend to shareholders.

headline: U.K. Shops Face Tobacco-Display Ban
summary: The U.K. government said it plans to ban the display of tobacco products in shops and may introduce plain packaging, as lawmakers seek to curb smoking and improve public health.

headline: E.ON's Profit Falls 31%
summary: German energy giant E.ON said net profit in 2010 fell 31% owing in part to lower disposal gains, and forecast its operating earnings this year would decrease by up to 16%.

headline: What, Them Worry? Traders Mostly Shrug Off Oil's Spike
summary: While the surge in oil prices may have driven some traders to distraction, a few of the options market's worry gauges are sending a calmer signal lately.

headline: Wholesale Inventories Rise
summary: U.S. wholesale inventories rose in January more than expected and sales surged, reflecting higher oil prices as well as suggesting confidence among businesses.

headline: 'Good' Northern Rock Posts Loss
summary: Northern Rock the "good bank" hived off from the nationalized U.K. mortgage lender, reported a £223.4 million net loss for 2010 but said its lack of profit shouldn't hinder its planned return to the private sector.

headline: Carbon Capture Projects Gain
summary: The race to deploy carbon capture and storage projects shifted to North America and away from Europe last year, according to an annual report on the sector, but industry watchers are keeping a close eye on China as well.

headline: American Eagle Profit Up
summary: American Eagle Outfitters profit rose 47% although sales declined. The company confirmed that CEO James O'Donnell will retire.

headline: Zippo Ads From the Past
summary: Zippo is expanding its lineup to include items such as cologne, but for decades it has been known for its 'windproof' cigarette lighters. See ads of Zippo's most iconic product.

headline: Australian Regulator Opposes Asahi Deal
summary: Asahi's drive to expand its global reach hit a roadblock when Australia's consumer regulator declared its opposition to the proposed purchase of P&N Beverages.

headline: Tullow, Uganda Agree on Sale Terms
summary: Tullow Oil has agreed terms with the Ugandan government that will allow it to sell a portion of its oil licenses in the country to Total and China National Offshore Oil Co.

headline: JCDecaux Eyes CBS Outdoor
summary: JCDecaux, the world's largest seller of outdoor advertising, is considering a bid for U.S. competitor CBS Outdoor.

headline: Doubt Cast on $5 Billion China-Sasol Deal
summary: Beijing appears to be stalling a $5 billion-plus deal with a South African petrochemicals company that would tap China's vast coal reserves to make synthetic fuels, while at the same time securing ways to acquire such technology domestically.

headline: U.K. Trade Deficit Shrinks
summary: The U.K.'s trade deficit shrank significantly in January as exports rose to the highest level since 1980, official data showed.

headline: Hannover Re Profit Rises 22%
summary: Hannover Re said its fourth-quarter net profit rose 22% as a substantially higher contribution from investments and higher premiums more than offset a moderate bill for major claims.

headline: Aeroflot Wraps Up Boeing Deal
summary: OAO Aeroflot completed a $2 billion deal with Boeing to purchase eight Boeing 777 airliners, with the first set for delivery in 2013.

headline: India Coffee Exports Likely to Jump
summary: India's coffee growers, encouraged by global prices surging to a near 14-year high, are queuing to export the beans and look set to boost shipments by about a fourth in the current quarter, industry executives said.

headline: Spain's Gamesa to Double India Capacity
summary: Spanish wind turbine maker Gamesa Corporacion Tecnologica SA is doubling its wind turbine manufacturing capacity in India by September with a five billion rupee ($110 million) investment, to cash in on the south Asian country's fast-growing renewable energy sector.

headline: India Shares End Higher for Second Day
summary: Indian shares closed higher for the second straight session amidst choppy trade Wednesday, tracking advances in Asian markets and supported by gains in Reliance Industries, India's largest company by market capitalization.

headline: Yunus Appeals Against Removal
summary: Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus filed an appeal Wednesday with Bangladesh's Supreme Court in his bid to overturn a central-bank order last week to remove him as head of the microfinance bank he founded.

headline: EU's Ashton Says EU to Expand Libya Sanctions
summary: The European Union's top foreign-policy officer said the EU will widen the scope of sanctions against the regime of Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi, and backed calls for a United-Nations-led investigation into events in Libya.

headline: Cathay Pacific Net Nearly Triples
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways said its 2010 net profit nearly tripled on a robust recovery in demand for passenger and cargo services as well as the sale of assets.

headline: A Taste of Indian Art
summary: Some snapshots of the contemporary art exhibition 'Indian Highway,' which brings together works by Nikhil Chopra, Bharti Kher and Subodh Gupta, among others.

headline: OZ Minerals Buys Copper Project
summary: Australian copper miner OZ Minerals will spend as much as $325 million buying a copper-gold project in South Australia state controlled by mining prospector Rudy Gomez.

headline: Greek Jobless Rate Accelerates
summary: Greece's unemployment rate continued to accelerate in December, rising to 14.8% compared with 10.2% in December 2009.

headline: Eli Lilly Back on Growth Track
summary: Drug maker Eli Lilly's chief executive said the company is banking on investment in research to pay off in the coming years as some key patents expire.

headline: EU Court Rejects Single-Patent Body
summary: The European Union's highest court said an EU proposal that would create a new system to litigate patents isn't compatible with EU law, a setback in a decades-long effort by EU nations to come up with a single-patent regime.

headline: Tata Consultancy Hopes to Recoup Iceland Loans
summary: India's Tata Consultancy Services said it remains a creditor to Iceland's Kaupthing Bank Hf, which went bankrupt in 2008 while the software exporter was offering some technology outsourcing services.

headline: India Car Sales Break New Record
summary: Automobile demand in India continued on a scorching drive, with car sales touching a monthly record in February, as customers advanced purchases on expectations of an increase in vehicle excise taxes by the federal government.

headline: Congress Reaches Agreement With DMK
summary: India's Congress party has finally resolved differences with south regional ally, the Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam party, averting a crisis that threatened the central government. Some snapshots.

headline: Satyam in Talks With SEC to Relist Faster
summary: Indian software exporter Satyam Computer Services, which is recovering from a fraud scandal, is in talks with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to shorten the time frame for which the company would need to restate its earnings under U.S. accounting standards, its chairman said.

headline: Reliance May Boost Gas Output From Key Block
summary: Reliance Industries may increase natural gas production at the D6 block in the Krishna-Godavari basin, off India's east coast, from April, the country's upstream regulator said.

headline: Vietnam Says Indian Corn No Good
summary: Vietnam has rejected Indian corn due to quality-related issues several times in past three months, trading executives said Wednesday, with the most recent occurrence involving at least 34 containers being rejected at Hai Phong port a few days ago.

headline: Flexing Muscles Before the Match
summary: India will play the Netherlands in a World Cup Group B match in New Delhi Wednesday. Some snapshots of India's cricketers in training.

headline: India Official: No Plan to Regulate Gasoline Prices
summary: India's federal government currently has no plan to regulate gasoline prices, a senior official in the country's oil ministry said.

headline: Qantas Raises Fuel Surcharges
summary: For the second time in two months, Qantas Airways increased the charges it adds to international fares to compensate for higher jet-fuel costs, joining airlines around the world attempting to shield themselves from the rise in crude-oil prices.

headline: Quake Rattles Northern Japan
summary: A 7.3-magnitude earthquake hit near northern Japan Wednesday morning, with the tremors felt as far as away as Tokyo, 260 miles to the south.

headline: Japan Names Matsumoto as Foreign Minister
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Naoto Kan named Takeaki Matsumoto, currently deputy foreign minister, as foreign minister, succeeding Seiji Maehara, who resigned due to a campaign funding scandal.

headline: Hollywood Sets Comeback
summary: Developments such as a planned eight-story office building at 1601 North Vine St., have begun to restore the vitality of Hollywood, Calif.

headline: Witness List Shown as Jury Selection Begins
summary: The U.S. judge presiding over the insider-trading trial of hedge-fund executive Raj Rajaratnam disclosed a list of scores of potential witnesses and testimony topics as he began questioning potential jurors Tuesday.

headline: Starbucks Menu Expands in China
summary: Starbucks is introducing its instant-coffee packets in China, expanding beyond coffee stores to also sell consumer packaged goods in China.

headline: Making Math Fun (Seriously)
summary: A skeptical Ralph meets Glen Whitney, the founder of the Museum of Math, scheduled to open in 2012.

headline: The NFL's Standardized Concussion Tests
summary: The NFL has announced standardized concussion-evaluation procedures to determine whether a player is fit to return to a game. No longer will a player be able to shrug and say, "It's nothing. I'm going back in."

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Richard W. Fisher says that further monetary accommodation won't speed up job creation.

headline: The Allman Brothers Come Home to Broadway
summary: The Allman Brothers Band has undertaken lengthy stays in New York City since 1989, outlasting even "Law & Order" as a local institution. The band returns to the Beacon Theatre this week.

headline: Ditmas Park Victorian
summary: The owner transformed what was once considered the most hideous home on the block in the historical district of Brooklyn's Ditmas Park neighborhood.

headline: Miners Pressed Over Bribery
summary: Governments in emerging and developed nations are tightening antibribery laws putting pressure on mining companies to better monitor employees and operations.

headline: Toll From Helicopter Strikes Climbs
summary: Even as U.S.-led forces have reduced the overall number of noncombatants they mistakenly kill or injure, deadly helicopter attacks on civilians have surged.

headline: Six Flags Enthusiasm
summary: Six Flags Entertainment shares have doubled since August, and management is betting the ride isn't over at the popular theme-park chain.

headline: Netanyahu Looks to Firm Support
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, facing opposition within his government to any new offer of territory to the Palestinians, made a rare visit to the Israeli-occupied Jordan Valley and vowed to keep a military presence in that strategic strip of the West Bank.

headline: A Barbershop Fight Turns Deadly
summary: An off-duty city department of corrections officer shot and killed a 77-year-old man Tuesday who approached him brandishing a pistol while the officer was sitting in a barber's chair getting a haircut in Brooklyn.

headline: Here, Tweeting Is a Class Requirement
summary: Businesses including Sprint Nextel, Levi Strauss and Mattel are sponsoring college classes and graduate-level research to get help with their online marketing from the young and hyperconnected.

headline: Sadanand Dhume: The Myth of 'Moderate Pakistan'
summary: The supposedly tolerant country has run out of easy options for weeding out Islamist fundamentalism.

headline: The People Get It, Congress Doesn't
summary: House Speaker John Boehner thinks the taxpayers don't get it ("GOP Aims to Tame Benefits Programs," page one, March 4)? Oh, we get it all right.

headline: Nansen G. Saleri: Our Man-Made Energy Crisis
summary: There's plenty of oil and no fundamental reason to expect prices of $200 per barrel. But that doesn't excuse the administration's punitive approach toward the industry.

headline: The Neighbors Should Handle Libya
summary: As usual, calls to impose a no-fly zone by various foreign leaders ("West Cools on No-Fly Zone," page one, March 3) can be interpreted as a summons for America to once again step in and do the dirty work.

headline: Bank Stocks Pique Manager's Interest
summary: An adviser for the Calvert Equity Portfolio fund, Richard England said he recently decided to overweight financials for the first time in the 12 years he has advised the fund, and to underweight the health-care sector.

headline: A Warm Welcome for the Shirt Dress
summary: The full-skirted silhouette is forgiving and flattering to many women.

headline: AIG Leasing Unit Resumes Aircraft Orders
summary: AIG's aircraft-leasing arm ordered 133 new planes from Airbus and Boeing, ILFC's first order since the crisis that engulfed AIG in 2008.

headline: Flood of IPOs to Test Hong Kong
summary: A slew of companies plan to seek as much as $8 billion from Hong Kong investors in coming months, testing the city's go-go market for IPOs at a time when foreign investors are pulling back from Asia.

headline: An Atlantic Party on the Hudson
summary: The Atlantic Theater Company—the off-Broadway outfit that birthed, among other hits, "Spring Awakening"—held its annual gala with something of a recession-era theme.

headline: Asking Price for 'Baby Jane' Duplex Rockets
summary: An Upper East Side duplex sold by Jane Holzer, once known as 'Baby Jane,'  in 2009 for $14.1 million is going back on the market at $23.5 million.

headline: Jenkins: What Price the Cloud?
summary: Companies betting heavily on high-speed mobile networks and high-powered applications have yet to confront the question of how the bandwidth will be paid for.

headline: Yankees Corner the Market on 2005 All-Stars
summary: If you're looking for 2005 All-Stars, look no further than the 2011 Yankees.

headline: CORRECTION
summary: The Obama administration is seeking Senate ratification of Protocol II to the Geneva Conventions, not Protocol I, as was stated in the March 8 editorial "Obama Ratifies Bush" (Review & Outlook). The administration says that from now on it will treat Article 75 of Protocol I as legally binding, though it has not been ratified by the Senate.

headline: India's Congress Seals Deal With Ally
summary: India's Congress party resolved differences with a regional ally in the southern state of Tamil Nadu, averting a political crisis that threatened Prime Minister Manmohan Singh's government.

headline: Guantanamo Order Delays Reckoning for 9/11 Suspects
summary: President Barack Obama's order to restart military trials at Guantanamo Bay and set policy on indefinite detentions stoked new questions about how to deal with alleged plotters of the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

headline: Downloading a Second Act
summary: When comedian Marc Maron found podcasting, he found a career rebirth.

headline: Property Battle for Gagfah
summary: Germany may be one of the hottest property-investment markets in Europe right now, but a political backlash against private-equity investors who bought German residential housing companies is spreading.

headline: Warner to Offer Movies via Facebook
summary: Warner Bros. said it will start renting movies via Facebook, the latest effort by movie studios to find new revenue sources as consumers buy fewer DVDs and spend more time online.

headline: Green Mountain Eclipses Starbucks
summary: Taking on Green Mountain in the single-serve-machine segment would be a tough proposition for Starbucks.

headline: Barcelona Apartment
summary: This five-bedroom home, which was created by combining two units in a luxury building, sits on a hill in Barcelona's Zona Alta.

headline: Last-Mover Disadvantage
summary: The move to Gibraltar should add a net £10 million ($16.2 million) to 2012 earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. But now that all the major online operators have moved offshore, including parts of state-owned Tote, it boosts the probability of the U.K. government finally demanding something in return. Options might include banning advertising in the U.K. for offshore operators or finding a new way to tax the companies. Having moved late, Betfair's earnings boost may be short-lived.

headline: Food Carts Fuel Black Market
summary: The city's competitive street-food culture has created a thriving black market for mobile food vending permits issued by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.

headline: Honda to Sell Hero Stake at Half Market Price
summary: Hero Honda Motors said one of its biggest founders will buy Honda Motor's 26% stake in the two-wheeler maker for about 38.42 billion rupees ($853 million), less than half the current market price.

headline: Goldman Names Co-Heads for Americas M&A
summary: Goldman Sachs Group has appointed Michael Carr and Dusty Philip as new co-heads of mergers and acquisitions for the Americas.

headline: Where Are the Shared Sacrifices, Productivity Gains?
summary: If Richard Trumka truly believes his own rhetoric in "Scott Walker's False Choice" (op-ed, March 4), the unions may be in deeper trouble than it appears.
